natural problem: No two students in Mrs. Vale's 26-student mathematics class have the same two initials. Each student's first name and last name begin with the same letter. If the letter ``Y'' is considered a vowel, what is the probability of randomly picking a student whose initials are vowels? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: The students' initials are AA, BB, CC, $\cdots$, ZZ, representing all 26 letters. The vowels are A, E, I, O, U, and Y, which are 6 letters out of the possible 26.
So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.

a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 No two students in Mrs. Vale's 26-student mathematics class have the same two initials. Each student's first name and last name begin with the same letter. If the letter ``Y'' is considered a vowel, what is the probability of randomly picking a student whose initials are vowels? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{13}
 ### Proof
 The students' initials are AA, BB, CC, $\cdots$, ZZ, representing all 26 letters. The vowels are A, E, I, O, U, and Y, which are 6 letters out of the possible 26.
 So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.
 *)

_with_same_letter"
shows  "vowels / students_with_vowels = 3 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a group of students, the ratio of students with names starting with a vowel to the total number of students with names starting with the same letter is 3:13.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and vowels :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum students {1..26} = 26"
and h1 : "sum vowels {1..6} = 6"
and h2 : "bij students"
and h3 : "bij vowels"
and h4 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> students i \<noteq> students j"
and h5 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> vowels i \<noteq> vowels j"
shows  "frac (sum vowels {1..6}) (sum students {1..26}) = 3 / 13"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 No two students in Mrs. Vale's 26-student mathematics class have the same two initials. Each student's first name and last name begin with the same letter. If the letter ``Y'' is considered a vowel, what is the probability of randomly picking a student whose initials are vowels? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{13}
 ### Proof
 The students' initials are AA, BB, CC, $\cdots$, ZZ, representing all 26 letters. The vowels are A, E, I, O, U, and Y, which are 6 letters out of the possible 26.
 So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat" and vowels :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum students {1..26} = 26"
and h1 : "sum vowels {1..6} = 6"
and h2 : "bij students"
and h3 : "bij vowels"
and h4 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> students i \<noteq> students j"
and h5 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> vowels i \<noteq> vowels j"
shows  "frac (sum vowels {1..6}) (sum students {1..26}) = 3 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a class of 26 students, each student is assigned a unique number from 1 to 26. Additionally, 6 of the students are assigned unique numbers from 1 to 6 corresponding to the vowels (A, E, I, O, U, and sometimes Y). What is the fraction of students that are assigned vowel numbers? The final answer is $\frac{3}{13}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: "nat \<Rightarrow> string \<times> string"
assumes h0 : "card (range students) = 26"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> students i \<noteq> students j"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. fst (students i) ! 0 = snd (students i) ! 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> c. is_vowel c = (c \<in> {'A', 'E', 'I', 'O', 'U', 'Y'})"
and h4 : "count_vowels = card {i. is_vowel (fst (students i) ! 0)}"
shows  "count_vowels / 26 = 3 / 13"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 No two students in Mrs. Vale's 26-student mathematics class have the same two initials. Each student's first name and last name begin with the same letter. If the letter ``Y'' is considered a vowel, what is the probability of randomly picking a student whose initials are vowels? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{13}
 ### Proof
 The students' initials are AA, BB, CC, $\cdots$, ZZ, representing all 26 letters. The vowels are A, E, I, O, U, and Y, which are 6 letters out of the possible 26.
 So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: "nat \<Rightarrow> string \<times> string"
assumes h0 : "card (range students) = 26"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i \<noteq> j \<longrightarrow> students i \<noteq> students j"
and h2 : "\<forall>i. fst (students i) ! 0 = snd (students i) ! 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> c. is_vowel c = (c \<in> {'A', 'E', 'I', 'O', 'U', 'Y'})"
and h4 : "count_vowels = card {i. is_vowel (fst (students i) ! 0)}"
shows  "count_vowels / 26 = 3 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a class of 26 students, each student has a unique first name and last name. The first letter of each student's first name is the same as the first letter of their last name. If the count of students whose names start with a vowel (A, E, I, O, U, Y) is `count_vowels`, find the fraction of students whose names start with a vowel. The final answer is $\frac{3}{13}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes student_count vowel_count :: nat
assumes h0 : "student_count = 26"
and h1 : "vowel_count = 6"
and h2 : "Y"
and h3 : "distinct (map (\<lambda>(f, l). (f, l)) (all_pairs (vowel_count, student_count)))"
shows  "probability_of_vowel_initials = (3::nat) / (13::nat)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 No two students in Mrs. Vale's 26-student mathematics class have the same two initials. Each student's first name and last name begin with the same letter. If the letter ``Y'' is considered a vowel, what is the probability of randomly picking a student whose initials are vowels? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{13}
 ### Proof
 The students' initials are AA, BB, CC, $\cdots$, ZZ, representing all 26 letters. The vowels are A, E, I, O, U, and Y, which are 6 letters out of the possible 26.
 So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes student_count vowel_count :: nat
assumes h0 : "student_count = 26"
and h1 : "vowel_count = 6"
and h2 : "Y"
and h3 : "distinct (map (\<lambda>(f, l). (f, l)) (all_pairs (vowel_count, student_count)))"
shows  "probability_of_vowel_initials = (3::nat) / (13::nat)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a class of 26 students, 6 of them have names that start with a vowel, including the letter 'Y'. What is the probability that a randomly selected student has a name that starts with a vowel? The final answer is $\frac{3}{13}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students_vowels students_total :: nat
assumes h0 : "students_vowels = 3"
and h1 : "students_total = 26"
shows  "students_vowels / students_total = 3 / 13"

fixes students_vowels students_total :: nat
assumes h0 : "students_vowels = 3"
and h1 : "students_total = 26"
shows  "students_vowels / students_total = 3 / 13"

a_4.informal problem: In a class of 26 students, 3 have names starting with a vowel. What is the fraction of students with names starting with a vowel? The final answer is $\frac{3}{13}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students :: nat
and vowels_initials :: nat
and vowels :: nat
and initials_same_letter :: bool
assumes h0 : "total_students = 26"
and h1 : "vowels_initials = 3"
and h2 : "vowels = 6"
and h3 : "\<forall> student1 student2. student1 \<noteq> student2 \<longrightarrow> (student1_initials \<noteq> student2_initials)"
shows  "vowels_initials_probability = (vowels_initials / total_students) = (3 / 13)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 No two students in Mrs. Vale's 26-student mathematics class have the same two initials. Each student's first name and last name begin with the same letter. If the letter ``Y'' is considered a vowel, what is the probability of randomly picking a student whose initials are vowels? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{13}
 ### Proof
 The students' initials are AA, BB, CC, $\cdots$, ZZ, representing all 26 letters. The vowels are A, E, I, O, U, and Y, which are 6 letters out of the possible 26.
 So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students :: nat
and vowels_initials :: nat
and vowels :: nat
and initials_same_letter :: bool
assumes h0 : "total_students = 26"
and h1 : "vowels_initials = 3"
and h2 : "vowels = 6"
and h3 : "\<forall> student1 student2. student1 \<noteq> student2 \<longrightarrow> (student1_initials \<noteq> student2_initials)"
shows  "vowels_initials_probability = (vowels_initials / total_students) = (3 / 13)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: In a class of 26 students, 3 students have vowels as their initials, and there are 6 different vowels. No two students have the same initials. What is the probability of a student having a vowel as their initial? The final answer is $\frac{3}{13}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_vowel :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "prob_vowel = 3 / 13"
shows  "prob_vowel = (card (UNIV :: {'A', 'E', 'I', 'O', 'U', 'Y'} set)) / (card (UNIV :: {'A'..'Z'} set))"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 No two students in Mrs. Vale's 26-student mathematics class have the same two initials. Each student's first name and last name begin with the same letter. If the letter ``Y'' is considered a vowel, what is the probability of randomly picking a student whose initials are vowels? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{3}{13}
 ### Proof
 The students' initials are AA, BB, CC, $\cdots$, ZZ, representing all 26 letters. The vowels are A, E, I, O, U, and Y, which are 6 letters out of the possible 26.
 So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_vowel :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "prob_vowel = 3 / 13"
shows  "prob_vowel = (card (UNIV :: {'A', 'E', 'I', 'O', 'U', 'Y'} set)) / (card (UNIV :: {'A'..'Z'} set))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the probability of selecting a vowel from the set of English alphabets. The vowels are considered to be A, E, I, O, U, and Y. The final answer is $\frac{3}{13}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes vowels_students total_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 26"
and h1 : "vowels_students = 6"
and h2 : "card (UNIV :: char set) = 26"
and h3 : "card {c. c \<in> UNIV \<and> is_vowel c} = 6"
shows  "vowels_students / total_students = 3 / 13"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes vowels_students total_students :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_students = 26"
and h1 : "vowels_students = 6"
and h2 : "card (UNIV :: char set) = 26"
and h3 : "card {c. c \<in> UNIV \<and> is_vowel c} = 6"
shows  "vowels_students / total_students = 3 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a group of 26 students, each student is assigned a unique letter from the English alphabet. There are 6 students whose assigned letters are vowels. What is the ratio of the number of students with vowel letters to the total number of students? The final answer is $\frac{3}{13}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_vowel :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_vowel = (\<Sum>vowel_students::real \<in> {3}. vowel_students) / (\<Sum>total_students::real \<in> {26}. total_students)"
shows  "prob_vowel = 3 / 13"
a_8.formal solution:

 So the probability of picking a student whose initials are vowels is $\frac{6}{26}=\boxed{\frac{3}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_vowel :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_vowel = (\<Sum>vowel_students::real \<in> {3}. vowel_students) / (\<Sum>total_students::real \<in> {26}. total_students)"
shows  "prob_vowel = 3 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a class of 26 students, 3 students have names that start with a vowel. What is the probability that a student chosen at random has a name that starts with a vowel? The final answer is $\frac{3}{13}$.

assumes h0 : "total_students = 26"
and h1 : "vowel_students = 3"
shows  "frac vowel_students total_students = frac 3 13"
